newsitem.title: GREECE: ATHLETICS-KIPKETER EYES LUCRATIVE WORLD RECORD.
newsitem.headline: ATHLETICS-KIPKETER EYES LUCRATIVE WORLD RECORD.

text.p: Wilson Kipketer, the Kenyan-born Dane with no need of a pacemaker, could become the first athlete to win the $100,000 bonus for breaking a world record at the world championships on Friday.
Kipketer broke the world indoor record twice running from the front at the world championships in Paris last March.
Last month in Stockholm, he took no notice of the pacemaker in the first lap but still recovered to equal Seb Coe's 16-year-old world mark of one minute 41.74 seconds.
"I don't care about any of the other competitors, I just run my own race," he said after accelerating through the field to win his second round race easily on Tuesday.
British triple jumper Jonathan Edwards, who broke the world record twice at the Gothenburg world championships two years ago, will also be competing on Wednesday.
Edwards, who prior to the championships had not competed for five weeks because of a heel injury, admitted he would be taking "a step in the dark".

Merlene Ottey defends her world 200 metres title with her chances enhanced by the absence of double Olympic champion Marie-Jose Perec who strained her right hamstring while warming up for her semifinal on Thursday.
Trinidad's Ato Boldon, who finished fifth in the 100 final on Sunday looked in impressive form on Thursday, winning his semifinal in 20.09.
His most dangerous rival on Friday should be 1993 world champion Frankie Fredericks of Namibia.
